unnormalised: ## Beyond the Blockbuster: Diving into the World of Film Festivals
normalised: ## Beyond the Blockbuster: Diving into the World of Film Festivals

unnormalised: Hey movie buffs! Ever felt like Bollywood just isn't cutting it? (No shade to SRK, of course!). Want something more, something different, a little…independent? Then you, my friend, need to explore the vibrant world of film festivals.
normalised: Hey movie buffs! Ever felt like Bollywood just isn't cutting it? (No shade to S R K, of course!). Want something more, something different, a little…independent? Then you, my friend, need to explore the vibrant world of film festivals.

unnormalised: Film festivals are like curated feasts for your eyes, showcasing everything from hard-hitting documentaries to experimental shorts you wouldn't find anywhere else. They’re a haven for independent filmmakers, a platform for diverse stories, and frankly, a really cool place to hang out.
normalised: Film festivals are like curated feasts for your eyes, showcasing everything from hard-hitting documentaries to experimental shorts you wouldn't find anywhere else. They’re a haven for independent filmmakers, a platform for diverse stories, and frankly, a really cool place to hang out.

unnormalised: Think of it this way: while PVR gives you the latest Salman Khan flick, a festival like the Mumbai Film Festival (MAMI) gives you a chance to discover a hidden gem from Kerala, or a thought-provoking drama from Iran. You might even stumble upon the next Anurag Kashyap, before he blows up the scene.
normalised: Think of it this way: while P V R gives you the latest Salman Khan flick, a festival like the Mumbai Film Festival (M A M I) gives you a chance to discover a hidden gem from Kerala, or a thought-provoking drama from Iran. You might even stumble upon the next Anurag Kashyap, before he blows up the scene.

unnormalised: Why should *you* care? Well, for starters, you get to watch films that challenge your perspective and broaden your horizons. You meet filmmakers, actors, and other passionate individuals who love cinema as much as you do. Plus, let's be honest, the post-screening discussions fueled by samosas and chai are totally worth it.

unnormalised: India has a thriving festival circuit. We have the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa, the Kolkata International Film Festival, and so many regional gems scattered across the country. Keep an eye out for smaller festivals happening in your city too! You might find one tucked away in a quaint Delhi neighbourhood, screening independent films for a week.

unnormalised: Attending a festival can seem intimidating at first. Don’t worry about knowing everything! Just grab a schedule, pick something that piques your interest, and dive in. The best part? Tickets are usually pretty affordable, often costing just Rs. 150-200 per screening, making it a budget-friendly way to expand your cinematic palate.

Tickets are usually pretty affordable, often costing just rupees one hundred and fifty to two hundred per screening, making it a budget-friendly way to expand your cinematic palate.

unnormalised: So, next time you're looking for something different to do on a weekend, ditch the same old multiplex experience and explore the world of film festivals. You might just discover your new favourite filmmaker or a film that changes the way you see the world. And who knows, maybe you'll even find yourself discussing it over a cup of chai 500 km away with a new friend!
